Generate and Instantiate What You Prefer: Text-Guided Diffusion for Sequential Recommendation

Guoqing Hu University of Science and Technology of China HugoChinn@mail.ustc.edu.cn ,Â  Zhengyi Yang University of Science and Technology of China yangzhy@mail.ustc.edu.cn ,Â  Zhibo Cai Renmin University of China caizhibo@ruc.edu.cn ,Â  An Zhang National University of Singapore anË™zhang@nus.edu.sg Â andÂ  Xiang Wang University of Science and Technology of China xiangwang1223@gmail.com
(2025)
Abstract.

Recent advancements in generative recommendation systems, particularly in the realm of sequential recommendation tasks, have shown promise in enhancing generalization to new items. Among these approaches, diffusion-based generative recommendation has emerged as an effective tool, leveraging its ability to capture data distributions and generate high-quality samples. Despite effectiveness, two primary challenges have been identified: 1) the lack of consistent modeling of data distribution for oracle items; and 2) the difficulty in scaling to more informative control signals beyond historical interactions. These issues stem from the uninformative nature of ID embeddings, which necessitate random initialization and limit the incorporation of additional control signals. To address these limitations, we propose iDreamRec to involve more concrete prior knowledge to establish item embeddings, particularly through detailed item text descriptions and advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM). More importantly, by converting item descriptions into embeddings aligned with TEM, we enable the integration of intention instructions as control signals to guide the generation of oracle items. Experimental results on four datasets demonstrate that iDreamRec not only outperforms existing diffusion-based generative recommenders but also facilitates the incorporation of intention instructions for more precise and effective recommendation generation.

Text Embeddings, Diffusion Models, Sequential Recommendation

1. Introduction

Recent advances in generative recommendation, especially in sequential recommendation scenarios (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Tang and Wang, 2018; Hidasi etÂ al., 2016), have shown promising results due to the ability to generalize better to new items (Rajput etÂ al., 2023; Yang etÂ al., 2023; Wang etÂ al., 2023a, b; Yu etÂ al., 2023). Among various generative frameworks, diffusion models (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Nichol and Dhariwal, 2021; Song etÂ al., 2021a; Song and Ermon, 2019, 2020; Song etÂ al., 2021b, 2023) have emerged as highly effective, largely due to their theoretical strengths in modeling complex data distributions and generating high-quality samples. For example, DreamRec (Yang etÂ al., 2023) employs a diffusion model, conditioned on the interaction histories of users, to predict the distribution of subsequent items (i.e., oracle items) and ground them to the real items users are likely to interact with. The learning objective in this framework is to generate oracle item embeddings through conditional diffusion processes, where the embeddings are simultaneously optimized alongside the model parameters.

Despite the effectiveness of DreamRec, we identify two inherent limitations that constrain its potential to fully exploit diffusion models in generative recommendation:

  • â€¢

    Inconsistent Data Distribution of Oracle Items. While diffusion models, in general, are excel in capturing consistent data distributions according to their theoretical underpinnings (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Song and Ermon, 2019; Song etÂ al., 2021b), DreamRec diverges from this principle. Instead of relying on pre-existing fixed item representations, DreamRec randomly initializes item embeddings which are then jointly optimized with model parameters during training. This process lacks a stable anchor in the latent space, causing item embeddings to fluctuate and evolve over time. Consequently, this instability leads to inconsistent data distribution for oracle items, ultimately degrading the performance of generative recommendation.

  • â€¢

    Limited Exploration to More Informative Controls. Although DreamRec effectively uses interaction histories as control signals to generate oracle items, it struggles to incorporate richer control signals, such as user intentions. For example, a user might express an intent like â€œI want to read a book about a young boy who discovers his magical heritage, attends a hidden school of wizardry, and confronts a dark evilâ€ (the example of intention in Figure 1(c)), which could lead to a recommendation like Harry Potter. However, as illustrated in Figure 1(b), the reliance on interaction histories limits the modelâ€™s ability to generate more nuanced and relevant recommendations, thereby constraining the full generative potential of diffusion models.

We attribute these limitations to a core issue: the reliance on learning item embeddings based solely on IDs. This not only requires random initialization, but also makes it challenging to incorporate additional control signals. A promising solution is to enrich item embeddings with more substantial prior knowledge beyond mere ID information. Furthermore, if the prior knowledge is interpretable by humans, it could enable the integration of intention instructions alongside interaction histories to better guide the generation process. Inspired by the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) (Brown etÂ al., 2020; Touvron etÂ al., 2023), leveraging the extensive world knowledge embedded within LLMs presents a valuable opportunity. However, how to effectively apply LLMs to create informative prior knowledge for item embeddings remains largely unexplored in diffusion-based generative recommendation. In this paper, we propose iDreamRec (intention-guided DreamRec), incorporating text embeddings from LLMs to accurately model item distributions and generate oracle items. Specifically, given the metadata about items (e.g., titles), we first prompt GPT (Brown etÂ al., 2020) to generate detailed textual descriptions, offering richer content than simple item IDs. To transform such descriptions into item embeddings, we employ the advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM) (Li etÂ al., 2023c; Liu etÂ al., 2019; Gao etÂ al., 2021; Muennighoff, 2022) provided by OpenAI 111https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/embeddings. This approach allows for converting variable-length descriptions into consistent, context-aware item embeddings. On this consistent embedding space, we train a diffusion model conditioned on interaction histories using a classifier-free guidance strategy (Ho and Salimans, 2022) as Algorithm 1. Crucially, as item embeddings align with TEM, intention instructions can also be translated into embeddings within the same space, providing refined control signals for generating oracle items (as shown in Figure 1(c)). Intent instructions can also be integrated with interaction histories to generate more nuanced and relevant oracle items (as illustrated in Figure 1(d)). For concrete examples, please refer to Figure 3.

Evaluations on four benchmark datasets suggest that iDreamRec not only outperforms current diffusion-based recommenders (e.g., DreamRec (Yang etÂ al., 2023), DiffRec (Wang etÂ al., 2023b)), but also enables the integration of intention instructions to guide the generation of oracle items.

2. Related Work

Diffusion models have shown extraordinary performance in various generative tasks, including image synthesis (Dhariwal and Nichol, 2021; Peebles and Xie, 2023), text generation (Li etÂ al., 2022; Gong etÂ al., 2023), 3D molecular modeling (Song etÂ al., 2024), biological sequence design (Avdeyev etÂ al., 2023) and anomaly detection (Livernoche etÂ al., 2024). The effectiveness of diffusion models stems from their training stability and high sampling quality in capturing the data distribution given observed samples compared to GANs (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2014; Arjovsky etÂ al., 2017) and VAEs (Kingma and Welling, 2014; MaalÃ¸e etÂ al., 2019). In general, diffusion models can be derived through the following three approaches: denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Song etÂ al., 2021a), score-based generative models (SGM) (Song and Ermon, 2019, 2020), and stochastic differential equations (SDE) (Song etÂ al., 2021b), which has theoretically shown to be equivalent and achieve similar performance in practice (Song etÂ al., 2021b; Luo, 2022). Specifically, SGM is a discrete form of variance-exploding SDE, while DDPM is a discrete form of variance-preserving SDE. In terms of application, works tend to adopt the DDPM framework (e.g., StableDiffusion (Rombach etÂ al., 2022), DiT (Peebles and Xie, 2023)) due to its flexibility in adapting to different scenarios.

Diffusion-based recommenders can be roughly classified into generative and discriminative ones according to their task formulation. Specifically, diffusion-based discriminative recommenders either predict interaction probability vectors for all items per user (Wang etÂ al., 2023b; BÃ©nÃ©dict etÂ al., 2023) or treat the diffusion model as a powerful enhancement for traditional discriminative recommenders, which is jointly trained under classification or ranking losses such as cross-entropy of Bayesian Personalized Ranking (Qin etÂ al., 2024; Li etÂ al., 2023b; Wang etÂ al., 2024; Du etÂ al., 2023). To fully leverage the powerful generative capability of the diffusion model, the diffusion-based generative recommender (i.e., DreamRec) reshapes sequential recommendation as generation of the subsequent item embedding (aka. oracle item embedding) under the condition of the interaction history (Yang etÂ al., 2023). However, DreamRec adopts randomly initialized and trainable ID embeddings similar to traditional sequential recommenders (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Tang and Wang, 2018; Hidasi etÂ al., 2016), which might bring practical challenges (as discussed in Section 1).

Text embedding model (TEM) aims to encode massive text into a unified semantic space with context awareness. Most TEMs are fine-tuned on large language models (LLM, e.g., BERT (Devlin etÂ al., 2019), T5 (Raffel etÂ al., 2020), GPT (Brown etÂ al., 2020)) with the contrastive learning objective. In the previous, BERT-based TEMs are widely used to acquire text embeddings for downstream tasks (Li etÂ al., 2023c; Liu etÂ al., 2019; Beltagy etÂ al., 2020; Gao etÂ al., 2021). Recently, as GPT (Brown etÂ al., 2020) has shown prevailing capability in natural language tasks, it becomes more promising to employ GPT-based TEMs, which are available via OpenAI Embedding API (Neelakantan etÂ al., 2022).

Large language models for recommendation (LLM4Recs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities. In general, LLM4Recs can be divided into LLM-based recommenders and LLM-enhanced recommenders. LLM-based recommenders consider LLM as the backbone of recommenders (Bao etÂ al., 2023b, a; Li etÂ al., 2023a; Liao etÂ al., 2024; Zhai etÂ al., 2024), while LLM-enhanced recommenders view LLM as a powerful feature extractor (Ren etÂ al., 2024; Wei etÂ al., 2024; Sheng etÂ al., 2024). Despite their powerful performance, LLM-based recommenders still face challenges such as high fine-tuning costs and relatively low recommendation efficiency. In practice, LLM-enhanced recommenders are more lightweight and feasible.

3. Preliminary

In this section, we introduce the diffusion-based generative recommendation, basically following DreamRec (Yang etÂ al., 2023). Here, denoising diffusion implicit models (DDIM) (Song etÂ al., 2021a) form the core of the diffusion framework. In contrast to the denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho etÂ al., 2020) originally employed in DreamRec, DDIM provides faster sampling and enhances sampling quality. See Appendix A for more details on DDIM and Table 2 for the symbol definitions.

4. Method

In this section, we introduce our proposed iDreamRec, aiming to build a more consistent item distribution for the diffusion-based generative recommendation, as well as involving intention instructions into the conditional guidance to generate more targeted and relevant oracle items.

4.1. Consistent Item Embedding Modeling

We identify that the core limitation of previous diffusion-based generative recommenders stems from uninformative ID embeddings, which might impair the generalization ability of diffusion models due to inconsistency during training (Daras etÂ al., 2023, 2024). To resolve this issue, we propose incorporating prior knowledge encoded in LLMs to create a more consistent embedding distribution of items for diffusion-based generative recommendation.

4.1.1. Prompting ChatGPT to Enrich Item Description

To create a more consistent embedding distribution of items than learnable ID embeddings, it is crucial to include richer prior knowledge about items. However, in real-world scenarios, the available information about items is often limited. To overcome this, we propose using ChatGPT (Brown etÂ al., 2020) to acquire more detailed and coherent descriptions of items, leveraging its extensive world knowledge. Specifically, given basic information of items ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v}bold_v (e.g., titles), we design prompts to extract more comprehensive descriptions from ChatGPT. Here is an example in the movie recommendation scenario:

By prompting ChatGPT, we can generate detailed descriptions for item vğ‘£vitalic_v, denoted as ğ’¯vsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

4.1.2. Embedding item description via Text Embedding Model

After enriching the item description (i.e., ğ’¯vsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) by prompting GPT, the next step is to construct a consistent item embedding distribution that effectively captures the information within ğ’¯vsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A straightforward approach is to leverage open-sourced Language Models (e.g., BERT (Devlin etÂ al., 2019), LLaMA (Touvron etÂ al., 2023)) to generate token-level embeddings of ğ’¯vsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, this presents practical challenges, as the length of descriptions varies significantly across items, which conflicts with the diffusion modelsâ€™ requirement for embeddings to have identical dimensions. While simple aggregation or pooling methods can generate embeddings with consistent dimensions, they may fail to adequately generalize or retain the necessary information.

Inspired by recent advances in Text Embedding Models (TEMs) (Li etÂ al., 2023c; Liu etÂ al., 2019; Beltagy etÂ al., 2020; Gao etÂ al., 2021; Ni etÂ al., 2022a, b; Neelakantan etÂ al., 2022), which are pre-trained to convert sentences into fixed-dimension embeddings while preserving semantics, we propose leveraging TEMs to generate embeddings for item descriptions. Specifically, for an item vğ‘£vitalic_v with a detailed description ğ’¯vsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we employ a TEM to obtain its corresponding embedding:

(7) ğv=TEM-Encâ¢(ğ’¯v),subscriptğğ‘£TEM-Encsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘£\mathbf{e}_{v}=\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\mathcal{T}_{v}),bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = TEM-Enc ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where TEM-Encâ¢(â‹…)TEM-Encâ‹…\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\cdot)TEM-Enc ( â‹… ) denotes the encoder of TEM, and ğvsubscriptğğ‘£\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the resulting text embedding. Since ğvsubscriptğğ‘£\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT encapsulates rich, relevant information from GPT and TEM, it remains frozen throughout training. Then, we obtain the text embedding matrix ğ„âˆˆâ„|â„|Ã—dğ„superscriptâ„â„ğ‘‘\mathbf{E}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{I}|\times d}bold_E âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_I | Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of all items in â„â„\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I, where dğ‘‘ditalic_d is the embedding dimension. Consequently, diffusion models can focus on capturing a more consistent distribution of items based on GPT-enhanced text embeddings from TEM, rather than relying on uninformative, trainable ID embeddings.

On the other hand, the transformed text embedding matrix ğ’œâ¢(ğ„)ğ’œğ„\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{E})caligraphic_A ( bold_E ) will be more evenly dispersed in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As a result, the row vectors of ğ’œâ¢(ğ„)ğ’œğ„\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{E})caligraphic_A ( bold_E ) will be maximally separated from each other, collectively filling the space of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as fully as possible (Lang, 2004; Axler, 1996; F.R.S., 1901). This makes it easier for the generated oracle item embeddings to find the most relevant items.

4.2. Intention Guidance via Text Embedding Models

As discussed in Section 1, another key limitation of current diffusion-based generative recommenders is the difficulty in incorporating more informative control signals, such as intention instructions, to guide the generation of oracle items. This is largely due to the fact that the randomly initialized item embeddings are hardly interpretable by humans (Daras etÂ al., 2023, 2024). In contrast, we have introduced TEM to acquire item embedding from textual descriptions of items, making them easier to understand in natural language. This allows us to incorporate intention instructions, which reflect user intentions or prior knowledge, into the control signal.

Specifically, consider an intention instruction denoted as ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y in natural language. Here is an example of intention instruction in the movie recommendation scenario:

By employing TEM-Encâ¢(â‹…)TEM-Encâ‹…\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\cdot)TEM-Enc ( â‹… ), the encoder of TEM on the top of ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, we can obtain the embedding of intention instruction ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y:

(12) ğğ’´=TEM-Encâ¢(ğ’´),subscriptğğ’´TEM-Encğ’´\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}=\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\mathcal{Y}),bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = TEM-Enc ( caligraphic_Y ) ,

where ğğ’´subscriptğğ’´\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the embedding of intention instruction, which lies in the same semantic space as the text embedding matrix of items ğ„ğ„\mathbf{E}bold_E due to the employ of the same TEM encoder.

To generate oracle items align with these intention instructions, we can simply modify the generation process in iDreamRec by fusing ğğ’´subscriptğğ’´\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the condition signal ğ<Lsubscriptğabsentğ¿\mathbf{e}_{<L}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from interaction histories:

In our experiments, we use a Diffusion Transformer (DiT) Block with in-context conditioning (Peebles and Xie, 2023).

Note that we do not explicitly involve intention instructions during the training process. Since the embedding of intention instruction ğğ’´subscriptğğ’´\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the item embedding ğvsubscriptğğ‘£\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are distributed in the same semantic space as the output space of TEM encoder, the intention instruction can be seamlessly integrated into the generation phase of iDreamRec as Algorithm 2, which can hardly be achieved in previous diffusion-based generative recommenders like DreamRec.

4.3. Recommendation Strategies under Various Linear Transformations

We are now capable of generating oracle item embeddings based on both interaction histories and intention instructions. However, as observed in previous work (Yang etÂ al., 2023), the generated oracle items may fall outside the candidate set. Therefore, we need recommendation strategies that adapt to linear transformations which preserve variance within DDIM, while facilitating the recommendation of actual items more effectively, as explained in Section 4.1.3.

4.3.1. Intention-understanding Recommendation under Dot-product Preserving

When set as ğ’œâ¢(ğ)=aâ¢ğ,ğ’œâ¢(ğ)=aâ¢ğğformulae-sequenceğ’œğğ‘ğğ’œğğ‘ğğ\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=a\mathbf{e},\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=a\mathbf{e}\mathbf% {O}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = italic_a bold_e , caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = italic_a bold_eO (ğğ\mathbf{O}bold_O is defined in Equation (8)), the linear transformation ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A preserves the order of dot product, i.e., âŸ¨ğ’œâ¢(ğ±),ğ’œâ¢(ğ²)âŸ©â‰¥âŸ¨ğ’œâ¢(ğ±),ğ’œâ¢(ğ³)âŸ©ğ’œğ±ğ’œğ²ğ’œğ±ğ’œğ³\langle\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{x}),\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{y})\rangle\geq\langle% \mathcal{A}(\mathbf{x}),\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{z})\rangleâŸ¨ caligraphic_A ( bold_x ) , caligraphic_A ( bold_y ) âŸ© â‰¥ âŸ¨ caligraphic_A ( bold_x ) , caligraphic_A ( bold_z ) âŸ© if âŸ¨ğ±,ğ²âŸ©â‰¥âŸ¨ğ±,ğ³âŸ©ğ±ğ²ğ±ğ³\langle\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\rangle\geq\langle\mathbf{x},\mathbf{z}\rangleâŸ¨ bold_x , bold_y âŸ© â‰¥ âŸ¨ bold_x , bold_z âŸ© for any ğ±,ğ²,ğ³ğ±ğ²ğ³\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z}bold_x , bold_y , bold_z. If transformation ğ’œâ¢(â‹…)ğ’œâ‹…\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( â‹… ) preserves the order of the dot product, the diffusion model can learn the dot product structure during training, enabling it to generate oracle item embeddings guided by user textual intention. Consequently, by recommending items that have the highest dot-product value with oracle item embedding, iDreamRec could retrieve real items in the candidate set under the guidance of both interaction histories and textual intention, as discussed in Section 4.2.

In addition to preserving dot-product, transformation ğ’œâ¢(â‹…)ğ’œâ‹…\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( â‹… ) also maintains the mean of the embeddings, either as ğ=aâ¢Meanâ¢(ğ„)ğğ‘Meanğ„\bm{\mu}=a\text{Mean}(\mathbf{E})bold_italic_Î¼ = italic_a Mean ( bold_E ) or ğ=aâ¢Meanâ¢(ğ„ğ)ğğ‘Meanğ„ğ\bm{\mu}=a\text{Mean}(\mathbf{E}\mathbf{O})bold_italic_Î¼ = italic_a Mean ( bold_EO ), implying the existence of distance between oracle item distribution qâ¢(ğL|ğ<L)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğğ¿subscriptğabsentğ¿q(\mathbf{e}_{L}|\mathbf{e}_{<L})italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pure noise ğ’©â¢(ğŸ,ğˆ)ğ’©0ğˆ\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{I})caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , bold_I ). During the inference process, the generation of oracle items could be achieved by gradually recovering oracle item embedding from pure noise as Equation (6). Therefore, more inference steps are required to preserve the order of the dot product and bridge the distance between the oracle item distribution and pure noise.

Under such circumstances, the inference process could be much more efficient in accuracy and time. Specifically, high recommendation accuracy can be achieved with a single-step generation, while multi-step generation further enhances it.

5. Experiments

In this section, we conducted extensive experiments to answer the following research questions:

  • â€¢

    RQ1: Could iDreamRec bring performance improvement by incorporating consistent item distribution modeling with Text Embedding Models?

  • â€¢

    RQ2: Could iDreamRec generate oracle items under the guidance of intention instructions?

  • â€¢

    RQ3: What are the main factors that impact the performance of iDreamRec?

5.1. Experimental Setup

Datasets. We use four real-world datasets:

  • â€¢

    Goodreads is collected from the Goodreads platform 222https://www.goodreads.com/. We utilize ChatGPT to generate missing genres and descriptions.

  • â€¢

    MovieLens (Harper and Konstan, 2016) is a commonly used movie recommendation dataset that contains user ratings, movie titles, and genres. For MovieLens, we utilize ChatGPT to generate descriptions.

  • â€¢

    Steam (Kang and McAuley, 2018) encompasses user reviews for video games on the Steam Store. For Steam, we utilize ChatGPT to generate descriptions.

  • â€¢

    Amazon-TV (Hou etÂ al., 2024) contains information and reviews for a wide range of movies on Amazon. Since the textual information is sufficiently rich, we do not prompt ChatGPT for any additional textual content.

In general, the four datasets represent different recommendation scenarios, while Amazon TV is more sparse, featuring over 40,000 items. The statistical information is shown in Table 3. We retain the 20-core datasets and filter out users and items with fewer than twenty interactions except MovieLens, which keeps the original dataset. Subsequently, we arrange all sequences chronologically and preserve the last 10 interactions as interaction history. For sequences with less than 10 interactions, we would pad them to 10 with a padding token. Then, we partition the data into training, validation, and testing sets at an 8:1:1 ratio. Regarding item text, we utilized GPT to enhance the textual information of the items, except for Amazon TV, which has sufficiently rich text information. Then, we concatenate the text information of items, including titles, genres, and descriptions, and input them into OpenAIâ€™s TEM text-embeddings-3-small to obtain textual item embeddings. For statistics of datasets, please refer to Table 3.

Compared Methods. We compare the proposed approach with the following baseline methods:

  • â€¢

    SASRec (Kang and McAuley, 2018) takes advantage of the self-attention mechanism in Transformer to capture usersâ€™ historical preference from interaction histories using learnable ID embedding.

  • â€¢

    Caser (Tang and Wang, 2018) uses horizontal and vertical convolutional filters to capture sequential patterns at the point-level, union-level to allow skip behaviors using learnable ID embedding.

  • â€¢

    MoRec (Yuan etÂ al., 2023) employs item characteristics derived from text descriptions encoded with a text encoder, or other modal information with its corresponding modal encoder, and performs dimensional transformation to align with SASRec.

  • â€¢

    UniSRec (Hou etÂ al., 2022) proposes an architecture based on parametric whitening and a mixture-of-experts enhanced adaptor to transform original text embeddings to adapt SASRec.

  • â€¢

    DiffRec (Wang etÂ al., 2023b), on behalf of diffusion-based discriminative recommendation models, utilizes diffusion models to model the distribution of probability vectors for each item per user.

  • â€¢

    DreamRec (Yang etÂ al., 2023), a diffusion-based generative recommender, reshape sequential recommendation as oracle item generation.

Overall, we compared traditional discriminative recommenders using trainable ID embeddings represented by SASRec and Caser, recommenders based on text embeddings represented by MoRec and UniSRec, and diffusion-based generative recommenders represented by DiffRec and DreamRec.

To ensure a fairer comparison, the methods based on text embeddings all utilize the same text embeddings from OpenAIâ€™s TEM text-embeddings-3-small as ours iDreamRec. After acquiring text embeddings by OpenAIâ€™s TEM text-embeddings-3-small, iDreamRec utilize linear transformation ğ€â¢(ğ)=(ğâˆ’ğ’–)â¢ğâ¢ğš²âˆ’12â¢ğTğ€ğğğ’–ğsuperscriptğš²12superscriptğğ‘‡\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\bm{\Lambda}^{-\frac{1}{2}% }\mathbf{O}^{T}bold_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O bold_Î› start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or ğ€â¢(ğ)=(ğâˆ’ğ’–)â¢ğâ¢Î›âˆ’12ğ€ğğğ’–ğsuperscriptÎ›12\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}bold_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O roman_Î› start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to preserve zero-mean and variance of identity matrix as section 4.3.2. Thereby, we could achieve one-step generative recommendation with high sampling quality. In our experiments, UniSRec and MoRec also get use of the same text embeddings instead of [CLS] embeddings from BERT.

Training Protocol. We implement all models with Python 3.7 and PyTorch 1.12.1 in Nvidia GeForce RTX 3090. We leverage AdamW as the optimizer. The embedding dimension of items is fixed as 1536 across all models. The learning rate is tuned in the range of {0.001,0.0001,0.00001,0.000001}0.0010.00010.000010.000001\left\{0.001,0.0001,0.00001,0.000001\right\}{ 0.001 , 0.0001 , 0.00001 , 0.000001 }. For SASRec, Caser, MoRec, and UniSRec, we use binary cross-entropy loss and perform negative sampling randomly at the ratio of {16,32,64}163264\left\{16,32,64\right\}{ 16 , 32 , 64 }, while there is no negative sampling in DiffRec, DreamRec, and our iDreamRec. For both DreamRec and our iDreamRec, we fix the unconditional training probability pğ‘pitalic_p as 0.1 suggested by (Ho and Salimans, 2022) and set the total diffusion step Tğ‘‡Titalic_T fixed as 2000, and the personalized guidance strength wğ‘¤witalic_w in the range of {0,2,4,6,8,10}0246810\left\{0,2,4,6,8,10\right\}{ 0 , 2 , 4 , 6 , 8 , 10 } as DreamRec. As for inference, DreamRec conducts Tğ‘‡Titalic_T-step generation while our iDreamRec achieves one-step generation.

Evaluation Protocol. We adopt two widely-used metrics to evaluate the performance of recommendation (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Yang etÂ al., 2023): hit ratio (HR@â¢K@ğ¾@K@ italic_K) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG@â¢K@ğ¾@K@ italic_K), where Kğ¾Kitalic_K is set to 5 and 10. And we calculate them based on the rankings of all items other than some sampled items. The full ranking strategy to some extent provides a fairer assessment (Krichene and Rendle, 2020).

5.2. Main Results (RQ1)

In this section, we compare iDreamRec with the baselines in terms of recommendation performance and analyze the reasons behind the results. The main experiment results are shown in Table 1.

In general, iDreamRec substantially outperforms compared approaches, highlighting the effectiveness of consistent item embedding modeling for diffusion-based generative recommenders, which is achieved by prompting ChatGPT and integrating pretrained Text Embedding Models in iDreamRec. Moreover, we can observe that DreamRec achieves pleasing performance on MovieLens and Goodreads data, while its performance on Steam and Amazon-TV is unsatisfactory. This performance gap can be attributed to that the inconsistency of randomly initialized ID embeddings would be amplified with the growth in the number of items, with much more items in Steam and Amazon-TV data than MovieLens and Goodreads. In contrast, iDreamRec models a more consistent embedding distribution of items, thus maintaining the best performance with a larger number of items.

5.3. Results with Intention Instructions (RQ2)

In this section, we progress to further demonstrate the intention instruction following the capability of iDreamRec, where a practical challenge lies in the lack of intention information in public recommendation datasets. To resolve this challenge, we compromise to prompt ChatGPT to generate the user intention ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y by providing a textual description of the item of interest to the user. Afterward, we examine whether iDreamRec could follow intention instruction ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y and provide higher recommendation accuracy towards the target item as discussed in Section 4.2. The results are shown in Figure LABEL:figIntention.

From Figure LABEL:figIntention we can observe that by varying the guidance strength of intention instructions, iDreamRec shows sensitiveness towards the prediction accuracy on target items, and could outperform historical interaction guidance under certain guidance strengths. Note that the intention instruction is not involved in the training of iDreamRec, and only integrated in the generation phase as described in Section 4.2, which implies the flexibility and stability of integrating more text-based guidance in iDreamRec.

5.4. Ablation Studys (RQ3)

To answer RQ3, we conducted ablation experiments to deeply analyze the contribution of key considerations in iDreamRec.

Firstly, we conduct an ablation experiment to analyze the impact of different types of embeddings on iDreamRec. The results are shown in Figure 4. To sum up, the consistency of item embeddings is a crucial adjective of the performance of iDreamRec, even diffusion-based generative recommenders. And rich item textual information will also be beneficial to the performance of iDreamRec with text embeddings. Moreover, even when using pre-trained ID embeddings, iDreamRec still demonstrates good performance, indicating that other types of consistent item embeddings are also applicable to iDreamRec.

Secondly, we conduct a study on the impact of recommender frameworks on text embeddings, with the results presented in Figure reffigText. The results demonstrate that diffusion-based recommenders can leverage consistent text embeddings from TEM more effectively than traditional recommenders.

5.5. Time Efficiency

The high inference time, a well-known drawback of diffusion models, renders diffusion-based recommenders impractical. Therefore, we will analyze the inference time efficiency of iDreamRec in this section. The results are shown in Figure 6. As shown in the figure, iDreamRec significantly improves inference efficiency compared to other diffusion-based recommendation systems, and it is even comparable to traditional recommenders.

6. Conclusion

We propose iDreamRec, which models consistent, context-aware embeddings encoded by advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM) and incorporates intention instructions for guiding the generation of the oracle item. Specifically, iDreamRec substantially encapsulates prior knowledge encoded in LLMs and TEMs into fixed item embeddings, thus nudging diffusion models to capture a more consistent oracle item distribution than ID embeddings. More importantly, the item embedding space of iDreamRec lies in accordance with the output space of TEM, allowing for the use of more informative intention instructions for oracle item generation. Experiments demonstrate that iDreamRec consistently enhances diffusion-based generative recommenders and enables the integration of intention instructions for more precise and effective recommendation results.

7. Limitation

There are also a few limitations of iDreamRec:

  • â€¢

    underexplored intention instructions: The intention instructions in iDreamRec are either heuristically constructed or generated by GPT, which differ from actual user inputs. It arises from the lack of real-world intention instruction data. Additionally, the effectiveness of intention guidance based on Text Embedding Models (TEM) is worth exploring. Our experiments revealed that, apart from the semantic of intentions, the syntactic structure might also has an impact as shown in Figure 3.

  • â€¢

    high latent dimension: The latent dimension of iDreamRec is determined by the output dimension of TEM, which is often significantly larger than the hidden dimension of traditional recommendation systems, typically set at 64.
